title: Dictionary Basics - Key-Value Pairs
objectives: Understand what dictionaries are and why they're useful
Learn to create and access dictionaries using keys
Master dictionary syntax with curly braces and colons
Compare dictionaries to lists and understand when to use each

sections.title: The Concept
sections.content:
ğŸ“– Dictionaries: Looking Things Up by Name

Real-World Analogy First:

Think about a real dictionary or phone book:

  • ğŸ“– Word â†’ Definition: You look up "python" and find "a large snake"
  • ğŸ“ Name â†’ Phone Number: You look up "Alice" and find "555-1234"
  • ğŸ« Seat Number â†’ Passenger: You look up "12A" and find who's sitting there

You don't flip through page by page (that's a list!). Instead, you go directly to what you're looking for using a KEY (the word, name, or seat number) to get the VALUE (definition, phone number, or passenger).

This is exactly how Python dictionaries work!

Now The Technical Term:

A dictionary is a collection of key-value pairs. Each key is unique and maps to a value. Instead of using numeric indices like lists [0, 1, 2], dictionaries use meaningful keys like names, IDs, or labels.

Key Differences from Lists:

ListsDictionaries
Access by position (index)Access by key (name)
Ordered by positionKeys map to values
my_list[0]my_dict['name']
Good for: sequencesGood for: lookups

Why Dictionaries Are Powerful:

  • âœ… Fast lookups: Finding a value by key is instant (no searching)
  • âœ… Meaningful keys: person['age'] is clearer than person[2]
  • âœ… Flexible structure: Keys describe what the data means
  • âœ… Real-world modeling: Perfect for representing objects with properties

When to Use Dictionaries:

  • âœ… When you need to look up values by name/ID/key
  • âœ… When data has labeled properties (like a person has name, age, email)
  • âœ… When order doesn't matter (or isn't the main concern)
  • âœ… When you need fast lookups by unique identifiers

sections.title: Code Example
sections.content:
ğŸ’» Creating and Using Dictionaries

Let's explore dictionaries with practical examples:
sections.code:
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 1: Creating Dictionaries
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 1: Creating dictionaries")
print()

# Empty dictionary
empty_dict = {}
print(f"Empty dictionary: {empty_dict}")
print()

# Dictionary with key-value pairs
person = {
    "name": "Alice",
    "age": 25,
    "city": "New York",
    "occupation": "Engineer"
}

print("Person dictionary:")
print(person)
print()

# Different types of keys and values
mixed_dict = {
    "text_key": "string value",
    "number_key": 42,
    "list_key": [1, 2, 3],
    "bool_key": True
}

print("Mixed types dictionary:")
print(mixed_dict)
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 2: Accessing Values by Key
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 2: Accessing dictionary values")
print()

person = {
    "name": "Bob",
    "age": 30,
    "email": "bob@example.com"
}

# Access using square brackets with key
name = person["name"]
age = person["age"]
email = person["email"]

print(f"Name: {name}")
print(f"Age: {age}")
print(f"Email: {email}")
print()

# Using in expressions
print(f"{person['name']} is {person['age']} years old.")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 3: Modifying Dictionaries
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 3: Adding and modifying values")
print()

product = {
    "name": "Laptop",
    "price": 999.99
}

print(f"Original: {product}")

# Add new key-value pair
product["brand"] = "TechCorp"
print(f"After adding brand: {product}")

# Modify existing value
product["price"] = 899.99
print(f"After price change: {product}")

# Add multiple properties
product["stock"] = 15
product["rating"] = 4.5
print(f"After adding more: {product}")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 4: Dictionary vs List Comparison
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 4: Dictionary vs List for storing person info")
print()

# Using a list (not ideal)
person_list = ["Carol", 28, "carol@example.com"]
print("As a list:")
print(f"  Data: {person_list}")
print(f"  Name: {person_list[0]}  (what's at index 0 again?)")
print(f"  Age: {person_list[1]}   (have to remember positions!)")
print()

# Using a dictionary (much better!)
person_dict = {
    "name": "Carol",
    "age": 28,
    "email": "carol@example.com"
}
print("As a dictionary:")
print(f"  Data: {person_dict}")
print(f"  Name: {person_dict['name']}  (clear and self-documenting!)")
print(f"  Age: {person_dict['age']}   (keys explain the data!)")
print()

# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
# EXAMPLE 5: Practical Use Case - Game Score
# â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

print("Example 5: Tracking game scores")
print()

# Player scores dictionary
scores = {
    "Alice": 1500,
    "Bob": 1200,
    "Carol": 1800,
    "Dave": 900
}

print("Current scores:")
for player, score in scores.items():
    print(f"  {player}: {score} points")
print()

# Update a score
scores["Bob"] = 1350
print(f"Bob's new score: {scores['Bob']}")

# Add new player
scores["Eve"] = 1100
print(f"\nAfter Eve joins:")
for player, score in scores.items():
    print(f"  {player}: {score} points")

# Find highest score
highest_score = max(scores.values())
print(f"\nHighest score: {highest_score}")

# Count players
print(f"Total players: {len(scores)}")

Mixed types dictionary:

Example 2: Accessing dictionary values

Name: Bob
Age: 30
Email: bob@example.com

Bob is 30 years old.

Example 3: Adding and modifying values

After adding brand: {'name': 'Laptop', 'price': 999.99, 'brand': 'TechCorp'}

Example 4: Dictionary vs List for storing person info

As a list:

As a dictionary:

  Age: 28   (keys explain the data!)

Example 5: Tracking game scores

Current scores:

  Bob: 1200 points
  Carol: 1800 points
  Dave: 900 points

Bob's new score: 1350

After Eve joins:
  Alice: 1500 points
  Bob: 1350 points
  Carol: 1800 points
  Dave: 900 points
  Eve: 1100 points

Highest score: 1800
Total players: 5

sections.title: Syntax Breakdown
sections.content:
ğŸ” Understanding Dictionary Syntax

Part 1: Creating a Dictionary

my_dict = {"key1": "value1", "key2": "value2"}
          ^                                   ^  
          curly braces
  • ğŸ“Œ Use curly braces {}
  • ğŸ“Œ Each entry is key: value (colon separates them)
  • ğŸ“Œ Multiple entries separated by commas
  • ğŸ“Œ Keys are usually strings (in quotes)
  • ğŸ“Œ Values can be any data type

Visual Structure:

person = {
    "name": "Alice",  â† key: value pair
    "age": 25,        â† comma between pairs
    "city": "NYC"     â† last pair (no comma)
}

KEY       VALUE
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€     â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
"name"  â†’ "Alice"
"age"   â†’ 25
"city"  â†’ "NYC"

Part 2: Accessing Values

person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}

# Access value by key
name = person["name"]  # "Alice"
       ^^^^^^ ^^^^^^  
       dict   key

# Use in expression
print(f"{person['name']} is {person['age']} years old.")
  • ğŸ“Œ Use square brackets [] with the key
  • ğŸ“Œ Key must be in quotes if it's a string
  • ğŸ“Œ Returns the value associated with that key
  • ğŸ“Œ If key doesn't exist: KeyError

Part 3: Adding and Modifying

# Adding new key-value pair
person["email"] = "alice@example.com"
       ^^^^^^^    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^  
       new key    value to store

# Modifying existing value
person["age"] = 26
       ^^^^^    ^^  
       existing  new value
       key
  • ğŸ“Œ If key doesn't exist: creates new entry
  • ğŸ“Œ If key exists: updates the value
  • ğŸ“Œ Same syntax for both operations!

Part 4: Key Types and Restrictions

# âœ… VALID keys (immutable types)
valid_dict = {
    "string_key": "value",      # String (most common)
    42: "value",                 # Integer
    3.14: "value",               # Float
    (1, 2): "value",             # Tuple (immutable)
    True: "value"                # Boolean
}

# âŒ INVALID keys (mutable types)
# bad_dict = {
#     [1, 2]: "value"            # List - TypeError!
#     {"a": 1}: "value"          # Dict - TypeError!
# }
  • ğŸ“Œ Keys must be immutable (unchangeable)
  • ğŸ“Œ Strings, numbers, tuples are OK
  • ğŸ“Œ Lists and dicts cannot be keys
  • ğŸ“Œ Keys must be unique (no duplicates)

Part 5: Common Dictionary Operations

person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25, "city": "NYC"}

# Check if key exists
if "name" in person:
    print("Name exists!")

# Get all keys
keys = person.keys()      # dict_keys(['name', 'age', 'city'])

# Get all values
values = person.values()  # dict_values(['Alice', 25, 'NYC'])

# Get all key-value pairs
items = person.items()    # dict_items([('name', 'Alice'), ...])

# Number of entries
count = len(person)       # 3

Part 6: Dictionary vs List

LIST:                          DICTIONARY:
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€           â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
fruits = ["apple",            person = {
          "banana",                "name": "Alice",
          "cherry"]                "age": 25
                                }

Access by INDEX:              Access by KEY:
fruits[0]  # "apple"          person["name"]  # "Alice"

Order matters                 Keys map to values
Position-based                Name-based lookup
Good for sequences            Good for properties

âš ï¸ Common Mistakes:

# âŒ WRONG - forgetting quotes on string keys
person = {name: "Alice"}  # NameError: name is not defined

# âœ… CORRECT
person = {"name": "Alice"}

# â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

# âŒ WRONG - using parentheses or brackets
person = ("name": "Alice")  # SyntaxError
person = ["name": "Alice"]  # SyntaxError

# âœ… CORRECT - use curly braces
person = {"name": "Alice"}

# â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

# âŒ WRONG - accessing non-existent key
person = {"name": "Alice"}
age = person["age"]  # KeyError: 'age'

# âœ… CORRECT - check first or use .get()
if "age" in person:
    age = person["age"]
# Or:
age = person.get("age", 0)  # Returns 0 if not found

sections.title: Exercise
sections.content:
âœï¸ Your Turn: Student Record System

Challenge: Create a dictionary to represent a student with their information, then perform various operations on it.

Requirements:

  1. Create a student dictionary with these keys:
    • "student_id": A number (e.g., 12345)
    • "name": Student's full name
    • "major": Field of study
    • "gpa": Grade point average (e.g., 3.5)
    • "graduation_year": Year they'll graduate
  2. Print the student information in a formatted way
  3. Update the GPA to a new value
  4. Add a new field "honors" set to True or False based on GPA >= 3.5
  5. Print the updated dictionary
  6. Calculate and print how many years until graduation (assume current year is 2024)

Example Output:

STUDENT RECORD
â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
ID: 12345
Name: Alice Johnson
Major: Computer Science
GPA: 3.5
Graduation Year: 2026

Updated GPA: 3.8
Honors Status: True

Years until graduation: 2
sections.starter_code:
# Create your student dictionary
student = {
    # Your key-value pairs here
}

# Print student information
print("STUDENT RECORD")
print("â•" * 30)
# Your printing code here

# Update GPA
# Your code here

# Add honors field (True if GPA >= 3.5)
# Your code here

# Print updated information
print("\nUpdated information:")
# Your code here

# Calculate years until graduation
current_year = 2024
# Your code here

sections.title: Solution
sections.code:
# Create student dictionary
student = {
    "student_id": 12345,
    "name": "Alice Johnson",
    "major": "Computer Science",
    "gpa": 3.5,
    "graduation_year": 2026
}

# Print student information
print("STUDENT RECORD")
print("â•" * 40)
print(f"ID: {student['student_id']}")
print(f"Name: {student['name']}")
print(f"Major: {student['major']}")
print(f"GPA: {student['gpa']}")
print(f"Graduation Year: {student['graduation_year']}")
print()

# Update GPA
print("ğŸ“ Updating GPA...")
old_gpa = student["gpa"]
student["gpa"] = 3.8
print(f"GPA changed from {old_gpa} to {student['gpa']}")
print()

# Add honors field based on GPA
student["honors"] = student["gpa"] >= 3.5
print(f"âœ¨ Honors status added: {student['honors']}")
print()

# Print updated dictionary
print("UPDATED STUDENT RECORD")
print("â•" * 40)
for key, value in student.items():
    # Format key to look nice
    formatted_key = key.replace("_", " ").title()
    print(f"{formatted_key}: {value}")
print()

# Calculate years until graduation
current_year = 2024
years_until_graduation = student["graduation_year"] - current_year

print("ğŸ“… GRADUATION INFO")
print("â•" * 40)
print(f"Current year: {current_year}")
print(f"Graduation year: {student['graduation_year']}")
print(f"Years remaining: {years_until_graduation}")

if years_until_graduation == 0:
    print("ğŸ“ Graduating this year!")
elif years_until_graduation < 0:
    print(f"ğŸ“ Already graduated {abs(years_until_graduation)} year(s) ago!")
else:
    print(f"ğŸ“š {years_until_graduation} more year(s) to go!")

print()

# Bonus: Summary based on data
print("ğŸ“Š SUMMARY")
print("â•" * 40)
status = "Honors student" if student["honors"] else "Regular student"
print(f"{student['name']} is a {status}")
print(f"studying {student['major']} with a {student['gpa']} GPA.")
if years_until_graduation > 0:
    print(f"Expected to graduate in {student['graduation_year']}.")

â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

Graduation year: 2026
Years remaining: 2
ğŸ“š 2 more year(s) to go!

ğŸ“Š SUMMARY
â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

studying Computer Science with a 3.8 GPA.
Expected to graduate in 2026.
sections.explanation:
ğŸ“š How It Works:

  1. Creating the Dictionary (Lines 2-8):
    student = {
    "student_id": 12345,      # Integer value
    "name": "Alice Johnson",  # String value
    "major": "Computer Science",
    "gpa": 3.5,               # Float value
    "graduation_year": 2026   # Integer value
}
    • Each line is a key: value pair
    • Keys are strings (in quotes)
    • Values can be different types (int, str, float)
    • Commas separate pairs
  2. Accessing Values (Lines 11-16):
    print(f"ID: {student['student_id']}")
print(f"Name: {student['name']}")
    • Use dictionary["key"] syntax
    • Keys must match exactly (case-sensitive)
    • Returns the value for that key
  3. Modifying a Value (Line 21):
    student["gpa"] = 3.8  # Updates existing value
    • Assign new value to existing key
    • Old value is replaced
    • Dictionary is mutable (can be changed)
  4. Adding a New Key-Value Pair (Line 27):
    student["honors"] = student["gpa"] >= 3.5
    • If key doesn't exist, it's created
    • Value is the result of the comparison (True/False)
    • Same syntax as modifying!
  5. Iterating Over Dictionary (Line 33):
    for key, value in student.items():
    • .items() returns key-value pairs
    • Each iteration gives you both key and value
    • Can process all entries in dictionary
  6. Calculations Using Dictionary Values (Line 40):
    years_until_graduation = student["graduation_year"] - current_year
    • Access values for calculations
    • Use dictionary data in logic
    • Values can be used like any variable

âš ï¸ Common Mistakes:

  1. Forgetting Quotes on String Keys:
    # âŒ WRONG
student = {name: "Alice"}  # NameError

# âœ… CORRECT
student = {"name": "Alice"}
  2. Typo in Key Name:
    student = {"student_id": 12345}
print(student["studentid"])  # âŒ KeyError: 'studentid'
print(student["student_id"]) # âœ… Works
  3. Trying to Access Non-Existent Key:
    student = {"name": "Alice"}
age = student["age"]  # âŒ KeyError: 'age'

# âœ… BETTER - check first
if "age" in student:
    age = student["age"]
else:
    age = None
  4. Using Wrong Brackets:
    # âŒ WRONG - parentheses
student = ("name": "Alice")

# âŒ WRONG - square brackets
student = ["name": "Alice"]

# âœ… CORRECT - curly braces
student = {"name": "Alice"}
  5. Duplicate Keys (Last One Wins):
    student = {
    "name": "Alice",
    "name": "Bob"  # This overwrites "Alice"
}
print(student["name"])  # Prints "Bob"

ğŸ’¡ Pro Tips:

  • âœ… Use descriptive keys: "student_id" is better than "id"
  • âœ… Consistent naming: Use snake_case for keys ("first_name" not "firstName")
  • âœ… Check before accessing: Use in keyword or .get() method
  • âœ… Store related data together: Dictionaries group related information logically
  • âœ… Values can be any type: Strings, numbers, lists, even other dictionaries!

sections.title: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
ğŸ¯ Essential Points to Remember:

  1. Dictionaries store key-value pairs:
    person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^  ^^^^^^^^^^  
          key: value       key: value
    • Keys map to values (like a real dictionary)
    • Fast lookups by key name
  2. Dictionary syntax:
    • Create: {"key1": value1, "key2": value2}
    • Access: dictionary["key"]
    • Add/Modify: dictionary["key"] = new_value
    • Use curly braces {}, not parentheses or brackets
  3. Keys must be:
    • Immutable (strings, numbers, tuples - NOT lists or dicts)
    • Unique (no duplicate keys)
    • Usually strings for readability
  4. Values can be any type:
    • Strings, numbers, booleans, lists, other dictionaries
    • Each key can have a different value type
  5. Dictionary vs List:
    ListsDictionaries
    my_list[0]my_dict["key"]
    Access by positionAccess by name
    Order mattersKeys map to values
    For sequencesFor labeled data
  6. Common operations:
    # Check if key exists
if "name" in person:

# Get number of items
count = len(person)

# Get all keys
keys = person.keys()

# Get all values
values = person.values()

# Get all pairs
items = person.items()
  7. Adding vs Modifying (same syntax!):
    person["email"] = "new@email.com"
# If "email" doesn't exist â†’ adds it
# If "email" exists â†’ updates it
  8. KeyError happens when key doesn't exist:
    person = {"name": "Alice"}
age = person["age"]  # KeyError!

# Prevent with:
if "age" in person:  # Check first
    age = person["age"]
  9. Use dictionaries when:
    • âœ… Data has labeled properties (person has name, age, email)
    • âœ… You need fast lookups by identifier
    • âœ… Order isn't the primary concern
    • âœ… You want self-documenting code (person["name"] vs person[0])
  10. Dictionaries are mutable:
    • Can add, modify, and remove entries
    • Changes affect the original dictionary
    • Like lists, not like strings/tuples

ğŸš€ Coming Up Next:

In the next lesson, you'll learn about Dictionary Methods and Operations - powerful tools like .get(), .update(), .pop(), and more for working with dictionaries efficiently and safely!

checkpoint_quiz.question: What is the correct syntax to create a dictionary with a key 'name' and value 'Alice'?
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: Use CURLY BRACES {} with key: value pairs separated by a colon. person = {'name': 'Alice'} is correct. Square brackets [] are for lists, parentheses () are for tuples, and angle brackets <> aren't used for collections in Python.

checkpoint_quiz.question: How do you access the value associated with the key 'age' in a dictionary named 'person'?
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: Use square brackets with the key: person['age']. This is similar to list indexing but you use the key name instead of a numeric index. The key must be in quotes if it's a string.

options: A new key-value pair is added to the dictionary
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: A NEW key-value pair is ADDED to the dictionary! If the key doesn't exist, Python creates it. If it does exist, Python updates it. Same syntax for both adding and modifying - this is different from accessing where missing keys cause errors.
